[[4th New Zealand Armoured Brigade|4th Armoured Brigade]] (1943–45) |garrison= |garrison_label= |nickname= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=Second World War :[[Battle of Greece]] :[[Battle of Crete]] :[[North African Campaign]] ::*[[Operation Crusader]] ::*[[First Battle of El Alamein]] :[[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]] ::*[[Battle of Monte Cassino]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |disbanded=December 1945 |commander1= |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= }} The '''18th Battalion''' was a formation of the [[New Zealand Army|New Zealand Military Forces]] which served, initially as an [[infantry]] [[battalion]] and then as an [[Armoured warfare|armoured]] [[regiment]], during the [[World War II|Second World War]] as part of the [[2nd New Zealand Division]]. The 18th Battalion was formed in New Zealand in September 1939 and after a period of training, it embarked for the [[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle East]] and then onto Greece in 1941 as part of the 2nd New Zealand Division. It participated in the [[Battle of Greece]] and later in the [[Battle of Crete|fighting on Crete]]. Evacuated from Crete, it then fought in the [[North African Campaign]] and suffered heavy losses during [[Operation Crusader]]. Brought back up to strength, the battalion participated in the breakout of the 2nd New Zealand Division from [[Minqar Qaim]] in June 1942, where it had been encircled by the [[21st Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|German 21st ''Panzer'' Division]]. The following month, the battalion fought in the [[First Battle of El Alamein]]. In October 1943, the battalion was converted to armour and re-designated the '''18th Armoured Regiment'''. To replace men lost at El Alamein, personnel were drawn from a tank brigade being formed in New Zealand. The regiment spent a year in Egypt training with [[M4 Sherman|Sherman tank]]s, before embarking for Italy in October 1943 to join up with the rest of the 2nd New Zealand Division. It participated in the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]], fighting in actions at [[Moro River Campaign|Orsogna]] and later at [[Battle of Monte Cassino|Cassino]]. The regiment finished the war in [[Trieste]] and remained there for several weeks until the large numbers of [[Yugoslav partisans]] also present in the city withdrew. Not required for service in the [[Pacific War|Pacific theatre of operations]], the regiment was disestablished in late 1945. ==History== ===Formation and training=== Following the outbreak of the Second World War, the New Zealand government authorised the formation of the [[2nd New Zealand Expeditionary Force]] (2NZEF), for service at home and abroad.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=16}} Following consultation with the British government, it was decided that the main New Zealand contribution to the war effort would be in the form of an infantry division, the [[2nd New Zealand Division]], under the command of Major General [[Bernard Freyberg, 1st Baron Freyberg|Bernard Freyberg]]. The new division would require nine battalions of infantry{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=19}} and consequently, several infantry battalions were formed from 1939 to 1940 with New Zealand volunteers.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=16}} The 18th Battalion{{#tag:ref|The numbering of the battalions raised for the 2NZEF followed that of the existing 17 infantry battalions of the [[Territorial Force (New Zealand)|Territorial Force]]. Thus, the 18th Battalion was the first battalion formed for the 2NZEF.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=21}}|group=Note}} was formed in September 1939 under the command of [[Lieutenant Colonel]] John Gray. It was the first of three infantry battalions designated to make up the first echelon of the 2nd New Zealand Division, destined for overseas service.{{#tag:ref|The other two infantry battalions were the [[19th Battalion (New Zealand)|19th]] and [[20th Battalion (New Zealand)|20th]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=6}}|group=Note}} Its personnel were all volunteers were drawn from the Northern Military District, which took in the upper half of the [[North Island]] of New Zealand. They were formed into four rifle companies, designated A to D and corresponding to the [[Auckland, New Zealand|Auckland]], Hauraki/Bay of Plenty/Rotorua, Northland and [[Waikato, New Zealand|Waikato]] districts.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=1–3}} A headquarters company included the specialist support troops; signallers, anti-aircraft and mortar platoons, pioneers and transport as well as administrative personnel.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=3–4}} A period of rudimentary training followed, firstly at [[Hopuhopu Military Camp]] and then at [[Papakura Military Camp|Papakura]],{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=6}} before it was confirmed that the battalion was on active service.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=10}} It departed New Zealand on the [[Orient Steam Navigation Company|Orient liner]] [[RMS Orion|RMS ''Orion'']] for the [[Middle East]] on 5 January 1940 as part of the [[4th Infantry Brigade (New Zealand)|4th Infantry Brigade]], 2nd Division New Zealand Division.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=13}} Before it left, it paraded before the public at the [[Auckland Domain]] and was addressed by the commander of the Northern Military District, Lieutenant Colonel [[Norman Weir]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=11}} The ''Orion'' journeyed to its destination as part of a convoy of liners{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=13–14}} by way of [[Fremantle]],{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=20}} [[Colombo]],{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=25}} and [[Aden]] before it arrived at [[Tewfik]], Egypt, where the battalion disembarked.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=26–27}} After a train ride to [[Cairo]], the battalion arrived at what would the main base in the Middle East for the 2NZEF, [[Maadi Camp]], in mid-February.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=30–31}} At Maadi, the battalion undertook further training. Following Italy's entry into the war in June, it moved to a newly established defensive position, the [[Baggush Box]], to perform garrison duty. It remained there for the next several months,{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|pp=263–265}} conducting regular patrols and working on the improvement of the defensive positions. During this time, the battalion suffered its first casualties of the war, although non-fatal, as a result of Italian air raids.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=59}} By January 1941, the defensive work was completed{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=64}} and the battalion moved to Helwan Camp, near Cairo, for re-equipping and more intensive and large scale training.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=67–68}} [[File:Maadi Military Camp.jpg|thumb|For a period in 1940, the 18th Battalion was based at Maadi military camp, seen here in 1941 with Cairo in the background]] ===Greece=== In early 1941, the British Government anticipated an [[Battle of Greece|invasion of Greece]] by the [[Nazi Germany|Germans]] and decided to send troops to support the Greeks, who were [[Greco-Italian War|already engaged]] against the Italians in [[Albania]]. The 2nd New Zealand Division was one of a number of Allied units dispatched to Greece in early March.{{sfn|McClymont|1959|p=103}} The 18th Battalion was the first New Zealand unit to depart Egypt, and sailed for Greece on 7 March aboard the [[Royal Navy]] cruisers [[HMS Orion (85)|HMS ''Orion'']] and [[HMS Ajax (22)|''Ajax'']].{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=67}} The 2nd New Zealand Division was tasked with the defence of the [[Aliakmon]] Line in northern Greece and was positioned on the northern side of [[Mount Olympus]]; the 4th Brigade manned the left side of the New Zealand section of the line while the [[6th Infantry Brigade (New Zealand)|6th Brigade]] took the right.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=69}} The 18th Battalion, was the first complete unit in the line; one company was positioned in Olympus Pass itself while the remainder started digging in the sector allocated to 4th Brigade.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=71}} By 5 April, the battalion's defensive work was completed.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=83}} On 6 April, the Germans invaded Greece and advanced so rapidly that their forces quickly threatened to outflank the New Zealand positions.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|pp=73–75}} On 9 April the 4th Infantry Brigade was withdrawn{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=84}} and began moving south to the [[Servia, Greece|Servia]] Pass. Here, 18th Battalion was positioned in the hills above the town of Servia and to the right of 19th Battalion, which was defending the pass itself.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=821}} From 11 April, [[Junkers Ju 87|Stukas]] mounted air raids on the New Zealand positions before the Germans brought artillery to bear two days later as their ground forces approached. It was during an artillery barrage on 15 April that the battalion suffered its first fatality of the war.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=92–94}} The same day, the 18th Battalion fended off initial probing attacks by elements of the [[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9th ''Panzer'' Division]] although the Germans did manage to occupy Servia.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=94–96}} Despite this, the battalions of 4th Brigade remained in good defensive positions. However, they were withdrawn two days later to the Thermopylae Line, a new defensive position {{convert|140|km|mi}} to the south, due to pressure on their flanks.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=96–97}} Walking out on foot under the cover of night and harassed by artillery fire, the withdrawal did not go smoothly. Having the furthest to travel, at one stage two companies of 18th Battalion got lost before making their way to the safety of the rear of Servia Pass and waiting transportation.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|pp=92–93}} Once clear of the pass, the battalion's transport was subjected to several air raids before they finally made it to the [[Battle of Thermopylae (1941)|Thermopylae Line]], the next defensive position for the New Zealanders.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=107–108}} The Thermopylae Line was defended by the 2nd New Zealand Division and [[6th Division (Australia)|6th Australian Division]], with the 4th Brigade held in reserve while the 5th and 6th manned the front lines.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=99}} However, on 22 April, the Allies decided to abandon Greece and the battalion moved out the same day with the rest of the 4th Brigade{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=110}} as part of an intended rearguard. Originally the battalion was to hold a gorge through which other units would pass for 24 hours but it ended up remaining there for three days. During the intervening period, the intended embarkation route for the battalion's departure from Greece was cut off by the Germans and so the entire brigade made its way to [[Porto Rafti]], east of [[Athens]],{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=118–119}} where the battalion was one of the first units of the 2nd New Zealand Division to be shipped to the island of [[Crete]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=112–114}} Total casualties during the campaign in Greece were 23 killed in action and 42 wounded. In addition, 117 men, mostly personnel recuperating in hospitals in Athens and unable to evade the Germans, were captured.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=122}} ===Crete=== Situated along vital air and sea lanes of communication in the middle of the Mediterranean, Crete was of considerable strategic importance to both sides and, after the conclusion of the campaign in Greece, the Allies fully expected that the Germans would attempt an invasion.{{sfn|Clark|2000|p=18}}{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|pp=124–128}} The 4th Brigade was stationed as a reserve force in the area around Galatas with the 18th Battalion near the newly established general hospital.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=124–125}} When the airborne invasion began on 20 May, the battalion quickly dealt with a company of [[Fallschirmjäger (World War II)|''Fallschirmjäger'']] (paratroopers) that landed near them.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=129–131}} It carried out mopping up operations and patrolled the area for the next two days before assisting the 19th Battalion in an attack on ''Fallschirmjäger'' that had established a strong defensive position nearby.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=136–137}} Despite heavy casualties during the initial attack, the Germans were able to land reinforcements and the situation on the island quickly deteriorated for the Allies. The brigade had abandoned its initial positions and moved to a new location to the west of Galatas to eliminate the threat that it would become separated from the [[5th Infantry Brigade (New Zealand)|5th Infantry Brigade]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=141–142}} On 25 May, the 18th Battalion had to deal with a full-scale attack by ''Fallschirmjäger''. This caused heavy casualties and a large portion of one of the battalion's company was captured. Despite reinforcements arriving from the 20th Battalion and the best efforts of Gray in rounding up stragglers, the Galatas position was breached and the township captured.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=148–151}} Some battalion personnel, led by Gray, along with the bulk of the [[23rd Battalion (New Zealand)|23rd Battalion]], participated in an attack that briefly took back the township but it later had to be abandoned again after further fighting.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=154–155}} The battalion was then withdrawn to the east as the order to evacuate Crete was received, making its way towards Suda Bay, where Allied ships were taking troops off the beaches. Along the way, they were subjected to heavy air raids, one of which killed a company commander, Captain [[Jack Lyon]], the [[Member of Parliament]] for the [[Waitemata (New Zealand electorate)|Waitemata electorate]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=156–157}} During the evacuation of the 4th Brigade, which took place from Sfakia on 30–31 May, the 18th Battalion formed a rearguard helping police and maintain order; it was the last battalion of the brigade taken off.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=166–167}} Casualties during the fighting on Crete were heavy for the 18th Battalion, with 105 men killed or missing and 110 more taken prisoner.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=168}} ===North Africa=== Back in its former base in Egypt and with its ranks restored with 400 reinforcements that arrived in June, the battalion began intensive weapons training.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=170–171}} In September it moved to Baggush where on occasion it worked alongside tanks in training exercises.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=175–177}} In November 1941, the battalion, now commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Joseph Peart as Gray had been hospitalised, participated in [[Operation Crusader]] as part of the [[British Eighth Army]] and was engaged in offensive operations towards the Sidi Azeiz area.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=181–182}} On the night of 25 November, along with the 20th Battalion, it was tasked with the night-time capture of Belhamed, a hill adjacent to Sidi Rezegh.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=198–199}} With two companies leading the battalion's portion of the advance, the objective was captured with a bayonet charge. Peart was wounded during the attack but remained in command.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|pp=227–228}} The battalion held the hill for three days before it swapped its positions with the 20th Battalion before, on 30 November, the [[15th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|15th ''Panzer'' Division]] surrounded and attacked Belhamed. While the 20th Battalion was effectively destroyed, the 18th Battalion managed to evacuate in time and reached the British [[70th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|70th Division]] in Tobruk.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=216–219}} Here it manned the lines, with Gray back in command, fending off German attacks, until 11 December when it was withdrawn to Baggush.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=229–230}} After a period near Cairo, in February 1942, the 2nd New Zealand Division was dispatched to Syria to defend against a possible attack through Turkey on the Middle East oilfields by the Germans.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=232–235}} Along with the rest of the 4th Brigade the 18th Battalion worked on defences to the north of Damascus{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=239}} before the whole division was recalled to Libya on 17 June following the attack on the Eighth Army's Gazala Line by [[Panzer Army Africa]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=247}} It was initially based at Mersa Matruh{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=264}} but after the fall of Tobruk to Rommel's forces, the division was ordered on 25 June to establish defensive positions at [[Minqar Qaim]]. The 18th Battalion was temporarily detached from the rest of the 4th Brigade to act as the main infantry component of the divisional reserve.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|pp=266–267}} On 27 June, the division's defensive positions at Minqar Qaim were encircled by the [[21st Panzer Division|21st ''Panzer'' Division]]. The battalion was one of the lead units in the subsequent breakout that night.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=259–260}} The battalion was withdrawn to the Alamein line after a brief period of recovery at the Kaponga Box.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=265}} Now commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Ray Lynch due to Gray being promoted to brigadier and given command of the 4th Brigade,{{#tag:ref|Gray was killed in an air raid shortly afterwards.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=270}}|group=Note}} it served as security for the divisional headquarters from late June to early July as the entire division relocated several times during this period.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=270}} On the evening of 14 July, the battalion, now back with its parent brigade, was part of the attack on Ruweisat Ridge, held by the enemy.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=275–276}} Although an Italian strongpoint caused the battalion to scatter, in piecemeal fashion, it advanced to the western end of the ridge taking several prisoners on the way.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=277–278}} A German counterattack in the afternoon of 15 July which overwhelmed the 19th and 20th Battalions also caused heavy losses amongst the 18th Battalion, including Lynch, but many men were able to return to the Allied lines.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=289–290}} Following the effective destruction of the 19th and 20th Battalions, the 18th Battalion remained in the field attached to the 5th Brigade. It then supported an attack by the 6th Brigade on El Mreir.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=295–297}} Inadequately supported by armour, the attack proved a failure although the battalion escaped with relatively few casualties.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=305}} It remained in the line throughout August and into September but, having been reduced to just 350 personnel, it was withdrawn to Maadi to rejoin the reconstituted 4th Brigade.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=327}} ===Conversion to armour=== It had previously been decided to form an armoured brigade to provide tank support to the 2nd New Zealand Division and as a result, the [[1st Army Tank Brigade (New Zealand)|1st New Zealand Army Tank Brigade]] was formed. This brigade was still undergoing training in New Zealand in September when it was decided to convert the 4th Brigade to armour instead, thus creating the [[4th New Zealand Armoured Brigade|4th Armoured Brigade]]. Personnel were transferred from the tank brigade in New Zealand to bring the 4th Brigade back up to strength. As one of the constituent units of the brigade, the 18th Battalion was officially re-designated the 18th Armoured Regiment, with three squadrons of tanks, on 5 October 1942.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=329–332}} One squadron was to be equipped with [[Crusader tank|Crusaders]]{{#tag:ref|These were later replaced with Shermans.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=343}}|group=Note}} with the other two squadrons operating [[M4 Sherman|Shermans]].{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=337}} The regiment would spend the next year in training under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Clive Pleasants, who had taken over command after the death of Lynch. By May 1943, many personnel had been on active duty for well over three years. The majority of these men were returned to New Zealand on furlough.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=340}} [[File:LC Pleasants, 1943.jpg|thumb|Lieutenant Colonel Clive Pleasants oversaw the conversion of the 18th Battalion from infantry to armour and led it through the early stages of the Italian Campaign]] With the close of the North African campaign in May 1943, attention then turned to the European theatre of operations. Despite a preference amongst some sections of the New Zealand government for the 2nd New Zealand Division to be redeployed to the [[Pacific Ocean theater of World War II|Pacific theatre of operations]] to fight against the Japanese, it was decided that the division would remain in Europe and continue its service with the Eighth Army. Accordingly, in October, the division was transferred to Italy.{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|p=248}} ===Italy=== The 18th Armoured Regiment disembarked at [[Taranto]] on 22 October 1943 and gradually travelled north towards the [[Sangro River]],{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=351–352}} which it duly crossed on 3 December.{{sfn|Plowman|2010|p=51}} In the following weeks, the regiment supported the 5th and 6th Brigades in their attack on [[Orsogna]], as part of the [[Moro River Campaign]]. Although the infantry made some gains, the German defences were too strong and the attack soon faded into a stalemate, with a number of back and forth actions as winter set in,{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|p=249}} which led to many of the regiment's tanks becoming stuck in the sodden ground.{{sfn|Plowman|2010|pp=85–86}} Offensive operations around Orsogna ceased in late December{{sfn|Plowman|2010|p=139}} and the New Zealanders withdrew from the area on 13 January 1944.{{sfn|Plowman|2010|p=147}} Following its withdrawal from the area around Orsogna, the 2nd New Zealand Division was one of a number of divisions that were transferred from the Eighth Army to the [[Fifth Army (United States)|Fifth Army]], then engaged on the western side of the [[Apennine Mountains|Apennines]]. This was part of an overall strategy to breach the [[Gustav Line]] and break an otherwise deadlocked Italian front. Together with the [[4th Indian Division]] and supporting British and American artillery, the division formed the [[New Zealand Corps]] with Freyberg, now a lieutenant general, in command. The corps moved to [[Cassino]], the defenders of which had resisted American forces for several weeks.{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|p=249}} As at Orsogna, the 18th Armoured Regiment was to play a supporting role in the forthcoming Cassino attack, with the infantry of the 5th and 6th Brigades bearing the brunt of the battle. When the attack began on 15 March, the regiment was initially held as a reserve, ready to exploit any breakthrough by the infantry but this did not eventuate. The infantry struggled to make progress in the face of determined resistance.{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|p=251}} The regiment's tanks were first used at Cassino as artillery support for two weeks, each squadron being rotated in three-day stints to a position overlooking the town.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=432–434}} Then in mid-April, one squadron was detached to remain on the Cassino front while the other two squadrons were withdrawn for training.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=437}} The regiment remained fragmented into May, for once training was completed, another squadron was detached and sent into Cassino itself to man tanks which had been effectively set up as pillboxes.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=443}} By the end of May, the regiment was reunited and at full strength.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=459}} It supported the infantry brigades as the 2nd New Zealand Division advanced to Florence, duly entering the city in August. After this, the division was transferred to the [[I Canadian Corps]], then on the Adriatic Coast, and advanced up to Rimini.{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|p=251}} On 19 and 20 October, the 4th Armoured Brigade was involved in its first and only action as a brigade in an attack towards the [[Savio River]], with the 18th Armoured Regiment on the right flank. This was primarily a tank action, in contrast to previous battles in which the armour supported the infantry.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=568–569}} The attack was a success and pushed the Germans across the Savio, although their progress had been slower than expected because of poor weather and muddy conditions.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=581–582}} [[File:18 Armoured Regiment (NZ) Sherman, 1945.jpg|thumb|right|A Sherman of the 18th Armoured Regiment ready to cross the Po River in Italy]] The New Zealanders advanced to the [[Lamone (river)|Lamone River]] in anticipation of a crossing but instead supported the British [[46th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|46th Division]] in its attack across the river on 3 December. During this operation, the tanks of the 18th Regiment fired 6,200 shells in a single day. It then attacked towards the [[Senio|Senio River]], supporting infantry from the 5th Brigade.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=590–593}} The division was positioned along the Senio River for three months, over the worst of the winter period.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=603}} The regiment spent most of this time behind the lines at [[Forlì]] or [[Faenza]], or on short spells on the Senio frontlines.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=605}} Relieved by a Polish unit in March 1945,{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=608}} the regiment returned to the front lines in early April after a period of rest.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=611–612}} It made a [[Spring 1945 offensive in Italy|series of advances]] against the retreating German rearguard and on 2 May, the 2nd New Zealand Division entered [[Trieste]]. While most of the German garrison quickly surrendered, it was necessary to deal with some diehard elements who refused to surrender to either the New Zealanders or the [[Yugoslav partisans]] also present in the city. The partisans were reluctant to allow Germans to surrender to the New Zealanders, and the regiment remained in Trieste for several weeks until the large numbers of Yugoslav partisans also present in the city withdrew.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=648–651}} Not required for service in the Pacific theatre of operations, the regiment was disestablished in December 1945.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=648–651}} During the war, the 18th Battalion and its successor, the 18th Armoured Regiment, lost nearly 320 officers and men either killed in action or who later died of their wounds. Of the exactly 350 personnel made prisoners of war, a further 21 men died while in captivity.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|p=663}} ==Honours== Seven members of the battalion, including three of its commanders,{{#tag:ref|Parata, Pleasants, and Ferguson.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=664–665}}|group=Note}} were awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] while another member was appointed an Officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]] and a second was made a member of the same order. Nine officers were awarded the [[Military Cross]] while two others received the Greek Military Cross. Three soldiers received the [[Distinguished Conduct Medal]] and 26 others the [[Military Medal]]. Twenty-one soldiers received awards of the Greek Silver and Bronze medals.{{sfn|Dawson|1961|pp=664–665}} The 18th Battalion and its successor, the 18th Armoured Regiment, was awarded the following
